title: Geth gets into bad state and eventually crashes...
body:
Hi there,

please note that this is an issue tracker reserved for bug reports and feature requests.

For general questions please use the gitter channel or the Ethereum stack exchange at https://ethereum.stackexchange.com.

#### System information

Geth version:  1.8.15-stable
OS & Version: Ubuntu (Docker/AWS instance)
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

#### Expected behaviour
The Geth software should be up and running and process incoming requests to add/retrieve data.

#### Actual behaviour

Initially, once the nodes are up, it looks fine.I create an account and mine gas. I am able to invoke add/get requests from my code and add/fetch data from the Ethereum backend. In other words, the functionality works as expected.

However, I noticed that after 2-3 hours, the Ethereum nodes get into a bad state where every transaction to add data to ethereum (I am using a send() call to do that) gives the following error:

```
(node:52) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Unhandled promise rejection. This error originated either by throwing inside of an async function without a catch block, or by rejecting a promise which was not handled with .catch(). (rejection id: 4)
(node:52) UnhandledPromiseRejectionWarning: Error: Returned error: insufficient funds for gas * price + value
```
eth.getBlock("latest").gasLimit returns a gas value that is sufficiently high for the transaction. Remember - such transactions did work initially when I started the Ethereum node.

Ultimately, the Ethereum node crashes with the following msg:

when I do a free or docker stats <container>, the numbers seem to be good.

I see that the CPU % is close to 100%. All along mining is going on, but not too many transactions.
I initially had a suspicion that this may be due to too much mining going on that is eating up CPU space. Hence I reduced the target gas limit, but that did not help either.

Either ways, a crash is not the right thing.

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour

Load Ethereum nodes on an AWS EC2 instance.

Here, again I see calls to unlockAccount and it looks like it is trying to get the account details from some keystore.

Well, most probable reason is that someone is trying to bruteforce unlock on your machine, over rpc from the internet. You should not expose RPC ports over internet, and definitely not the `personal` namespace. Luckily, `scrypt` is memory hard, and they crash your system while doing so too many times.
alternatively, you're running with too little memory to do a full decryption. If that's the case, you need to either add more mem, or re-save the keys using the `lightkdf` option
I think we can chalk this up to a remote attack. Please never expose your RPC to the world. People are actively trying to connect to it an brute for the keys.

Thanks for the response Martin and Peter. I have already closed the RPC
ports as suggested.
